title: Emphasizing Tests, Biden Vows to Fight Omicron With ‘Science and Speed’
content: The president’s plan shifts away from a near-singular focus on vaccination, as new cases of the variant have emerged in the United States.

title: In Biden’s Plan for Free Rapid Tests, Legwork Will Be Required
content: Some nations make Covid tests available at little to no cost for consumers. The U.S. plan for home testing includes submitting receipts to private insurers.

more_info.byline: By Sarah Kliff and Reed Abelson

title: Why Didn’t the U.S. Detect Omicron Cases Sooner?
content: Genomic surveillance has improved enormously in recent months, but the system has built-in delays, and blind spots remain.

org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Most Covid Vaccines Will Work as Boosters, Study Suggests
content: In a comparison of seven different brands, researchers found that most shots give a strong boost, even in mix-and-match combinations.

title: Prior Infection Is Little Defense Against Virus Variant, Scientists Say
content: Evidence from South Africa, where the Omicron variant already dominates, shows a high rate of reinfection of people who have already had the coronavirus.

more_info.byline: By Lynsey Chutel and Richard Pérez-Peña

title: New York City Sets Vaccine Mandate for Religious and Private School Workers
content: The directive, which affects 56,000 employees, faced immediate opposition from some Jewish and Catholic leaders, who sent a letter to Mayor Bill de Blasio urging him to reconsider.

title: Congress Approves Spending Bill, Averting Government Shutdown
content: The vote to fund the government through mid-February came after lawmakers staved off a Republican threat to force a shutdown over vaccine mandates.

title: How the Politics of Abortion Are Poised to Intensify
content: The anti-abortion and abortion rights movements are already beginning to mobilize for a new, deeply unsettled post-Roe political reality.

more_info.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Jeremy W. Peters

title: How the Suburbs Have Changed Gerrymandering
content: Republicans have historically used the suburbs to defend against the electoral threat of cities. Now the suburbs themselves are posing the threat.

content: Oxford High School held repeated trainings on how to handle a gunman in school. But some critics are questioning their purpose.

title: What Does It Mean to Save a Neighborhood?
content: Nine years after Hurricane Sandy, residents of Lower Manhattan are still vulnerable to rising seas. The fight over a plan to protect them reveals why progress on our most critical challenges is so hard.

title: Dear People of 2021: What Can We Learn From Hindsight?
content: For the first series from the Headway initiative, we followed up on forecasts from decades past to ask what the passage of time has revealed.

title: Millions More People Got Access to Water. Can They Drink It?
content: The U.N. pledged to halve the proportion of the world without access to clean drinking water by 2015.

title: Extreme Poverty Has Been Sharply Cut. What Has Changed?
content: The U.N. pledged to cut by half the proportion of people living in the worst conditions around the world.

title: Hundreds of Companies Promised to Help Save Forests. Did They?
content: Cargill, Nestle, Carrefour and others pledged to reach net-zero deforestation in their supply chains by 2020.

title: A Car a Minute Used to Flow Through Here, but Chaos Now Reigns
content: A shipping terminal in Kansas reveals the fundamental problem — no one can plan, and no one is sure what will happen next.

title: With No Resources, Authority or Country, Afghan Ambassador Presses On
content: Adela Raz arrived in Washington just before her country fell and has struggled to keep her embassy going. A dinner with U.S. veterans was a priority.

title: He Says He’s No Murderer. That’s Why He’s Still in Prison.
content: Joseph Gordon has been locked up for nearly 30 years. A model inmate, he is eligible for parole — but only if he expresses remorse for a crime he says he did not commit.

title: Notable Deaths 2021
content: Remembering Hank Aaron, Colin Powell, Stephen Sondheim, Beverly Cleary, DMX, Cicely Tyson, Larry King, Olympia Dukakis, Chuck Close, Michael K. Williams, Janet Malcolm and many others who died this year.

title: Omicron Is Here. Should You Cancel Your Trip?

content: What the orthopedist saw on the X-rays surprised him.

content: The trend is towards liberalizing reproductive freedom, not repressing it.

content: More than 100,000 Americans died of overdoses in a single year, exceeding the number of people who died from car crashes and guns combined.
